awd_titl_txt: New Approach to Building a Workforce Pipeline for Electro-mechanical Technician Education
awd_abstract_narration:
In Northeast Wisconsin, the demand for skilled electro-mechanical technicians continues to exceed the supply of qualified applicants.  This project builds a collaboration between Northeast Wisconsin Technical College, the Northeast Wisconsin Manufacturing Alliance, and local industry to meet the regional need for electro-mechanical technicians.  These partners work together to design and implement strategies that can interest current entry-level workers in pursuing an Industrial Maintenance Certificate.  This certificate is the first step toward an Electro-Mechanical Associate Degree, but does not require the level of mathematics needed in later courses in the curriculum.  To prepare certificate students for success in the associate degree courses, this project aims to interweave math lessons into the lab portion of the certificate courses. In this way, the project expects that students will learn math concepts at the beginning of the career pathway, and will develop the confidence and math comprehension needed to succeed in the associate degree program.

Activities will include development of curriculum and educational materials to contextualize math and student success skills within the program courses. The project will support the laboratory needs of rural students by providing equipment upgrades. By the end of three years, it is expected that the project will benefit at least 60 entry-level adults, five college faculty, and multiple regional industry employers. This project will use multiple platforms to disseminate the practices and knowledge gained by the project to other regions. The project will specifically study how technical colleges and industry partners work together to encourage enrollment in an educational pathway to create a career pipeline.  This research will add to the current body of knowledge surrounding industry engagement in education and barriers to returning adults.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NEW (Northeast Wisconsin) Approach to Building a Workforce Pipeline project focused on increasing the number of skilled Electro-Mechanical Technicians by collaborating with the Northeast Wisconsin Manufacturing Alliance (NEWMA) and local industry to generate interest among current entry-level/low-skilled workers in pursuing career pathways to an Electro-Mechanical Associate Degree by starting with the embedded Industrial Maintenance Certificate. Northeast Wisconsin Technical College (NWTC) intentionally created the Industrial Maintenance Certificate with only technical courses to eliminate the barrier math creates for many students and meet employer demand for hiring individuals with a base set of skills. To prepare certificate students for success in their associate degree studies where math skills are integral, this project interweaved math lessons into the lab portion of the certificate courses. Project objectives included: 1) Increase entry-level/low-skilled worker knowledge of college system and career ladder; 2) Increase confidence level of adult learners entering the Electro-Mechanical career pathway; and 3) Reduce barriers to working adults. The project impacted over 100 entry-level/low-skill adults, five college faculty, and numerous major regional industry employers.

Intellectual Merit. For the manufacturing sector to remain strong in Northeast Wisconsin and other parts of the country, the ability to find skilled workers to fill positions is critical. New strategies are needed to address shortages and build a pipeline of skilled workers. The NEW Approach to Building a Workforce Pipeline project hypothesized that providing additional education to the currently employed adult population is the quickest and most efficient way to fill vacant positions. Research shows adult learners face different barriers than students enrolling in post-secondary education directly upon completing high school and that industry partners are crucial when building an educational solution to workforce needs. The project specifically looked at how technical colleges and industry partners can work together to encourage enrollment in an educational pathway to create a sustainable career pipeline and examine whether attitudes towards mathematics are preventing adult learners from continuing their education and training in STEM careers.  

Broader Impacts. The need for skilled manufacturing technicians has never been greater, particularly in Northeast Wisconsin where manufacturers are projecting growth but struggling to find talent to fill current positions. The NEW Approach to Building a Workforce Pipeline project sought to address these shortages by implementing new strategies for recruiting and assisting entry-level/low-skill adults to obtain educational training to advance their careers and secure technician-level jobs. Given the position of Wisconsin as the number one state in the nation for the highest manufacturing job concentration and the vital role manufacturing plays across the nation and world, the project utilized multiple platforms for dissemination of best practices and knowledge acquired for potential replication within manufacturing-dominate regions.

 


Last Modified: 07/27/2023
Modified by: Jill Thiede
